Create standard variables with dmcognigen

Source: vignettes/calculations.Rmd
calculations.Rmd

The calculations family is a collection of functions intended to facilitate the calculation of variables that mostly use standard equations (e.g: CrCl, eGFR, BMI etc). This vignette shows and explains:

  • How these functions work when expected variables are not passed.
  • The sample data integrated in the package, and how you can use it to practice.
  • Description of calculations functions.
  • Examples from different use cases.

Loading calculations

By installing dmcognigen package and loading it into your environment, you will have access to the calculations functions.

Assuming you already have dmcognigen package installed on your machine, then you load it into your environment:

library(dmcognigen)
library(dplyr)

Detect missing variables from environment

There’s a common behavior between all calculations functions when all or some of expected variables are missing. They will try to detect and use those missing variables from environment, details below:

  • It identifies the missing variables/inputs, if found, then
  • It looks in the environment to see if it contains those missing variables (it’s a case-insensitive match)
  • It’ll stop and pass error if either no match found or more than one matches found
  • If only one match found, then it’ll be used in calculation and user will be notified

Source datasets

In order to provide some examples and facilitating the testing for users, we’ve integrated some calculation ready sample datasets into the package. Once you’ve loaded the package, you can simply access them by calling their names.

dmcognigen_cov %>%
  mutate(
    CRCL = calculate_crcl(
      age = AGE,
      wtkg = WTKG,
      scr = SCR,
      sexf = SEXF
    )
  ) %>%
  select(USUBJID, AGE, WTKG, SCR, SEXF, CRCL)
#> Formula to calculate CRCL: 
#>   Males: CrCl = ((140 - AGE [year]) × WTKG) ÷ (72 × SCr [mg/dL])
#>   Females: CrCl = (((140 - AGE [year]) × WTKG) ÷ (72 × SCr[mg/dL])) × 0.85
#> # A tibble: 254 × 6
#>    USUBJID       AGE  WTKG   SCR  SEXF  CRCL
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015    63  54.4   0.9     1  55.0
#>  2 01-701-1023    64  80.3   1.4     0  60.5
#>  3 01-701-1028    71  99.3   1.4     0  68.0
#>  4 01-701-1033    74  88.4   1.5     0  54.1
#>  5 01-701-1034    77  62.6   1       1  46.6
#>  6 01-701-1047    85  67.1   1       1  43.6
#>  7 01-701-1097    68  78.0   1.4     0  55.7
#>  8 01-701-1111    81  59.9   0.9     1  46.3
#>  9 01-701-1115    84  78.9   1.3     0  47.2
#> 10 01-701-1118    52  71.2   1       0  87.0
#> # ℹ 244 more rows

dmcognigen_cov

The dmcognigen_cov dataset is a data.frame type. It contains the necessary variables to test and practice the calculation functions. Some variables like SCR are already created in this dataset, so you don’t need to create it.

Functions

Each function calculates a specific variable, but the same function can be used to calculate both baseline and time varying of a variable because it depends on the inputs. For instance, calculate_bmi can calculate both BMI and BMIT. If you provide time varying WTKG and HTCM, then the output will be a time varying BMI. Additionally, each function prints the equation that was used to calculate in a readable format.

calculate_crcl

The calculate_crcl function is to Calculate Creatinine Clearance (CrCl), a measure of renal function based on age, weight, gender, and Serum Creatinine. This is the Cockcroft and Gault Calculation. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
Males: CrCl = ((140 - AGE [year]) × WTKG) ÷ (72 × SCr [mg/dL])
Females: CrCl = (((140 - AGE [year]) × WTKG) ÷ (72 × SCr[mg/dL])) × 0.85

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • age: Age (y). Numeric vector.
  • wtkg: Weight (kg). Numeric vector.
  • scr: SCR (Serum Creatinine, mg/dL). Numeric vector.
  • sexf: Sex. Numeric vector including values of 0 and/or 1. 0=Male; 1=Female.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    CRCL = calculate_crcl(
      age = AGE,
      wtkg = WTKG,
      scr = SCR,
      sexf = SEXF
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, AGE, WTKG, SCR, SEXF, CRCL)
#> Formula to calculate CRCL: 
#>   Males: CrCl = ((140 - AGE [year]) × WTKG) ÷ (72 × SCr [mg/dL])
#>   Females: CrCl = (((140 - AGE [year]) × WTKG) ÷ (72 × SCr[mg/dL])) × 0.85
#> # A tibble: 254 × 6
#>    USUBJID       AGE  WTKG   SCR  SEXF  CRCL
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015    63  54.4   0.9     1  55.0
#>  2 01-701-1023    64  80.3   1.4     0  60.5
#>  3 01-701-1028    71  99.3   1.4     0  68.0
#>  4 01-701-1033    74  88.4   1.5     0  54.1
#>  5 01-701-1034    77  62.6   1       1  46.6
#>  6 01-701-1047    85  67.1   1       1  43.6
#>  7 01-701-1097    68  78.0   1.4     0  55.7
#>  8 01-701-1111    81  59.9   0.9     1  46.3
#>  9 01-701-1115    84  78.9   1.3     0  47.2
#> 10 01-701-1118    52  71.2   1       0  87.0
#> # ℹ 244 more rows
Example 2

All or some of expected variables are missing. In this case, the function will try to detect those missing variables from the parent environment:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    CRCL = calculate_crcl()
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, AGE, WTKG, SCR, SEXF, CRCL)

calculate_crcl_peck

The calculate_crcl_peck function is to Calculate Creatinine Clearance (CrCl) using the Peck Formula, a measure of renal function based on age, ideal weight, gender, and Serum Creatinine. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
If WTKG = 120% of IBW:
Males: CrCl = ((140 - AGE) × IBW) ÷ (72 × SCr)
Females: CrCl = (((140 - AGE) × IBW) ÷ (72 × SCr)) × 0.85

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • age: Age (y). Numeric vector.
  • wtkg: Weight (kg). Numeric vector.
  • crcl: Creatinine Clearance
  • ibw: Ideal Body Weight (kg). Numeric vector.
  • scr: SCR (Serum Creatinine, mg/dL). Numeric vector.
  • sexf: Sex. Numeric vector including values of 0 and/or 1. 0=Male; 1=Female.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    CRCLP = calculate_crcl_peck(
      age = AGE,
      wtkg = WTKG,
      crcl = CRCL,
      ibw = IBW,
      scr = SCR,
      sexf = SEXF
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, AGE, WTKG, CRCL, IBW, SCR, SEXF, CRCLP)
#> Formula to calculate CRCL_PECK: 
#>   If WTKG < 120% of IBW, CrCl = CRCL (Cockroft & Gault)
#>   If WTKG >= 120% of IBW:
#>     Males: CrCl = ((140 - AGE) × IBW) ÷ (72 × SCr)
#>     Females: CrCl = (((140 - AGE) × IBW) ÷ (72 × SCr)) × 0.85
#> # A tibble: 254 × 8
#>    USUBJID       AGE  WTKG  CRCL   IBW   SCR  SEXF CRCLP
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015    63  54.4  55.0  43.4   0.9     1  43.8
#>  2 01-701-1023    64  80.3  60.5  59.0   1.4     0  44.5
#>  3 01-701-1028    71  99.3  68.0  70.2   1.4     0  48.0
#>  4 01-701-1033    74  88.4  54.1  68.3   1.5     0  41.7
#>  5 01-701-1034    77  62.6  46.6  51.3   1       1  38.2
#>  6 01-701-1047    85  67.1  43.6  44.7   1       1  29.0
#>  7 01-701-1097    68  78.0  55.7  63.7   1.4     0  45.5
#>  8 01-701-1111    81  59.9  46.3  54.8   0.9     1  46.3
#>  9 01-701-1115    84  78.9  47.2  72.9   1.3     0  47.2
#> 10 01-701-1118    52  71.2  87.0  72     1       0  87.0
#> # ℹ 244 more rows

dmcognigen_cov %>%

calculate_bmi

The calculate_bmi function is to Calculate Body Mass Index (BMI). BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
BMI = WTKG ÷ (HTCM ÷ 100) ^ 2

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • wtkg: Weight (kg). Numeric vector.
  • htcm: Height (cm). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    BMI = calculate_bmi(
      wtkg = WTKG, 
      htcm = HTCM
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, WTKG, HTCM, BMI)
#> Formula to calculate BMI: 
#>   BMI = WTKG ÷ (HTCM ÷ 100) ^ 2
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID      WTKG  HTCM   BMI
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015  54.4  147.  25.1
#>  2 01-701-1023  80.3  163.  30.4
#>  3 01-701-1028  99.3  178.  31.4
#>  4 01-701-1033  88.4  175.  28.8
#>  5 01-701-1034  62.6  155.  26.1
#>  6 01-701-1047  67.1  149.  30.4
#>  7 01-701-1097  78.0  169.  27.3
#>  8 01-701-1111  59.9  158.  23.9
#>  9 01-701-1115  78.9  182.  23.9

calculate_bsa

The calculate_bsa function is to Calculate Body Surface Area (BSA). Body Surface Area is a measure of body fat based on height and weight. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
BSA = ((HTCM) ^ 0.42246 * (WTKG) ^ 0.51456) * .0235

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • htcm: Height (cm). Numeric vector.
  • wtkg: Weight (kg). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    BSA = calculate_bsa(
      htcm = HTCM, 
      wtkg = WTKG
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, HTCM, WTKG, BSA)
#> Formula to calculate BSA: 
#>   BSA = ((HTCM) ^ 0.42246 * (WTKG) ^ 0.51456) * .0235
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID      HTCM  WTKG   BSA
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015  147.  54.4  1.51
#>  2 01-701-1023  163.  80.3  1.93
#>  3 01-701-1028  178.  99.3  2.23
#>  4 01-701-1033  175.  88.4  2.09
#>  5 01-701-1034  155.  62.6  1.66
#>  6 01-701-1047  149.  67.1  1.69
#>  7 01-701-1097  169.  78.0  1.93
#>  8 01-701-1111  158.  59.9  1.64

calculate_lbm

The calculate_lbm function is to Calculate Lean Body Mass (lbm), an estimation of how much someone weighs without the body fat - how much a persons bones, organs and muscles weigh. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
Males: LBM = (1.10 × WTKG) - 128 × ((WTKG) ^ 2 ÷ (HTCM) ^ 2)
Females: LBM = (1.07 × WTKG) - 148 × ((WTKG) ^ 2 ÷ (HTCM) ^ 2)

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • sexf: Sex. Numeric vector including values of 0 and/or 1. 0=Male; 1=Female.
  • wtkg: Weight (kg). Numeric vector.
  • htcm: Height (cm). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    LBM = calculate_lbm(
      sexf = SEXF,
      wtkg = WTKG,
      htcm = HTCM
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, SEXF, WTKG, HTCM, LBM)
#> Formula to calculate LBM: 
#>   Males: LBM = (1.10 × WTKG) - 128 × ((WTKG) ^ 2 ÷ (HTCM) ^ 2)
#>   Females: LBM = (1.07 × WTKG) - 148 × ((WTKG) ^ 2 ÷ (HTCM) ^ 2)
#> # A tibble: 254 × 5
#>    USUBJID      SEXF  WTKG  HTCM   LBM
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015     1  54.4  147.  38.0
#>  2 01-701-1023     0  80.3  163.  57.1
#>  3 01-701-1028     0  99.3  178.  69.3
#>  4 01-701-1033     0  88.4  175.  64.7
#>  5 01-701-1034     1  62.6  155.  42.8
#>  6 01-701-1047     1  67.1  149.  41.6
#>  7 01-701-1097     0  78.0  169.  58.5
#>  8 01-701-1111     1  59.9  158.  42.9
#>  9 01-701-1115     0  78.9  182.  62.6
#> 10 01-701-1118     0  71.2  180.  58.4
#> # ℹ 244 more rows
Example 2

All or some of expected variables are missing. In this case, the function will try to detect those missing variables from the parent environment:

    LBM = calculate_lbm()
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, SEXF, WTKG, HTCM, LBM)

calculate_ibw

The calculate_ibw function is to Calculate Ideal Body Weight (IBW), a measure of potential body fat based on height. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
Males: IBW = 51.65 kg + 1.85 kg × ((HTCM ÷ 2.54) - 60)
Females: IBW = 48.67 kg + 1.65 kg × ((HTCM ÷ 2.54) - 60)

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • sexf: Sex. Numeric vector including values of 0 and/or 1. 0=Male; 1=Female.
  • htcm: Height (cm). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    IBW = calculate_ibw(
      sexf = SEXF, 
      htcm = HTCM
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, SEXF, HTCM, IBW)
#> Formula to calculate IBW: 
#>   Males: IBW = 51.65 kg + 1.85 kg × ((HTCM ÷ 2.54) - 60)
#>   Females: IBW = 48.67 kg + 1.65 kg × ((HTCM ÷ 2.54) - 60)
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID      SEXF  HTCM   IBW
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015     1  147.  43.4
#>  2 01-701-1023     0  163.  59.0
#>  3 01-701-1028     0  178.  70.2
#>  4 01-701-1033     0  175.  68.3

#>  6 01-701-1047     1  149.  44.7
#>  7 01-701-1097     0  169.  63.7
#>  8 01-701-1111     1  158.  54.8
#>  9 01-701-1115     0  182.  72.9

calculate_ibw_child

The calculate_ibw_child function is to Calculate Ideal Body Weight (for children), a measure of potential body fat based on height. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
IBW = [(HTCM) ^ 2 × 1.65] ÷ 1000

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following is the input:

  • htcm: Height (cm). Numeric vector.

Examples

calculate_egfr

The calculate_egfr function is to Calculate Estimated Glomerular Filtration Fate (eGFR) for adults. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
EGFRMDRD = 175 × (SCR ^ -1.154) × (AGE ^ -0.203) × (0.742 if female) × (1.212 if African American)

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • scr: SCR (Serum Creatinine, mg/dL). Numeric vector.
  • age: Age (y). Numeric vector.
  • sexf: Sex. Numeric vector including values of 0 and/or 1. 0=Male; 1=Female.
  • racen: Race. Numeric vector where the value 2 is expected to correspond to Black/African American.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    EGFR = calculate_egfr(
      scr = SCR,
      age = AGE,
      sexf = SEXF,
      racen = RACEN
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, SCR, AGE, SEXF, RACEN, EGFR)
#> Formula to calculate EGFR: 
#>   EGFRMDRD = 175 × (SCR ^ -1.154) × (AGE ^ -0.203) × (0.742 if female) × (1.212 if African American)
#> # A tibble: 254 × 6
#>    USUBJID       SCR   AGE  SEXF RACEN  EGFR
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015   0.9    63     1     1  63.2
#>  2 01-701-1023   1.4    64     0     1  51.0
#>  3 01-701-1028   1.4    71     0     1  50.0
#>  4 01-701-1033   1.5    74     0     1  45.7
#>  5 01-701-1034   1      77     1     1  53.8
#>  6 01-701-1047   1      85     1     1  52.7
#>  7 01-701-1097   1.4    68     0     1  50.4
#>  8 01-701-1111   0.9    81     1     1  60.1
#>  9 01-701-1115   1.3    84     0     1  52.6
#> 10 01-701-1118   1      52     0     1  78.5
#> # ℹ 244 more rows
Example 2

All or some of expected variables are missing. In this case, the function will try to detect those missing variables from the parent environment:

    EGFR = calculate_egfr()
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, SCR, AGE, SEXF, RACEN, EGFR)

calculate_egfr_child

The calculate_egfr_child function is to Calculate Estimated Glomerular Filtration Fate (eGFR) for Pedatrics using the Schwartz formula. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
Children (AGE 

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs.
Following are the inputs:
  • htcm: Height (cm). Numeric vector.
  • scr: SCR (Serum Creatinine, mg/dL). Numeric vector.
  • age: Age (y). Numeric vector.
  • sexf: Sex. Numeric vector including values of 0 and/or 1. 0=Male; 1=Female.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    EGFR_CHILD = calculate_egfr_child(
      htcm = HTCM,
      scr = SCR,
      age = AGE, 
      sexf = SEXF
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, HTCM, SCR, AGE, SEXF, EGFR_CHILD)
#> Formula to calculate EGFR_CHILD: 
#>   Children (AGE <= 16), where:
#>   egfr_child = (k * htcm) / scr (mg/dL)
#>   k = 0.45 for AGE <= 1 (full term)
#>   k = 0.55 for girls 1 < AGE <= 16
#>   k = 0.55 for boys 1 < AGE < 13
#>   k = 0.70 for boys 13 <= AGE <= 16
#> # A tibble: 254 × 6
#>    USUBJID      HTCM   SCR   AGE  SEXF EGFR_CHILD

#>  2 01-701-1023  163.   1.4    64     0         NA
#>  3 01-701-1028  178.   1.4    71     0         NA
#>  4 01-701-1033  175.   1.5    74     0         NA
#>  5 01-701-1034  155.   1      77     1         NA
#>  6 01-701-1047  149.   1      85     1         NA
#>  7 01-701-1097  169.   1.4    68     0         NA

calculate_rfcat

The calculate_rfcat function is to Calculate Renal Function Category (RFCAT). Following is the formula to calculate it: 
1 = Normal Function (>= 90 mL/min)
2 = Mild Impairment (60-89 mL/min)
3 = Moderate Impairment (30-59 mL/min)
4 = Severe Impairment (15-29 mL/min)
5 = End Stage Disease (

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs.
Following is the input:
  • egfr: Estimated Glomerular Filtration Fate (mL/min/1.73m^2). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    EGFR = calculate_egfr(
      scr = SCR,
      age = AGE,
      sexf = SEXF,
      racen = RACEN
    ),
    RFCAT = calculate_rfcat(egfr = EGFR)
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, EGFR, RFCAT)
#> Formula to calculate EGFR: 
#>   EGFRMDRD = 175 × (SCR ^ -1.154) × (AGE ^ -0.203) × (0.742 if female) × (1.212 if African American)
#> Formula to calculate RFCAT: 
#>   1 = Normal Function (>= 90 mL/min)
#>   2 = Mild Impairment (60-89 mL/min)
#>   3 = Moderate Impairment (30-59 mL/min)
#>   4 = Severe Impairment (15-29 mL/min)
#>   5 = End Stage Disease (< 15 mL/min or Dialysis)
#> # A tibble: 254 × 3
#>    USUBJID      EGFR RFCAT
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015  63.2     2
#>  2 01-701-1023  51.0     3
#>  3 01-701-1028  50.0     3
#>  4 01-701-1033  45.7     3
#>  5 01-701-1034  53.8     3
#>  6 01-701-1047  52.7     3
#>  7 01-701-1097  50.4     3
#>  8 01-701-1111  60.1     2
#>  9 01-701-1115  52.6     3
#> 10 01-701-1118  78.5     2
#> # ℹ 244 more rows
Example 2

All or some of expected variables are missing. In this case, the function will try to detect those missing variables from the parent environment:

  mutate(
    RFCAT = calculate_rfcat()
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, EGFR, RFCAT)
#> EGFR variable found and used for the egfr argument.
#> Formula to calculate RFCAT: 
#>   1 = Normal Function (>= 90 mL/min)
#>   2 = Mild Impairment (60-89 mL/min)
#>   3 = Moderate Impairment (30-59 mL/min)
#>   4 = Severe Impairment (15-29 mL/min)
#>   5 = End Stage Disease (< 15 mL/min or Dialysis)
#> # A tibble: 254 × 3
#>    USUBJID      EGFR RFCAT
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015  63.2     2
#>  2 01-701-1023  51.0     3
#>  3 01-701-1028  50.0     3
#>  4 01-701-1033  45.7     3
#>  5 01-701-1034  53.8     3
#>  6 01-701-1047  52.7     3
#>  7 01-701-1097  50.4     3
#>  8 01-701-1111  60.1     2
#>  9 01-701-1115  52.6     3
#> 10 01-701-1118  78.5     2
#> # ℹ 244 more rows

calculate_tbilcat

The calculate_tbilcat function is to Calculate TBIL Category. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
if TBIL  3 × ULN then TBILCAT = 3

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • tbil: Total Bilirubin (mg/dL). Numeric vector.
  • tbiluln: Reference Range Upper Limit (same units as observed values). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    TBILCAT = calculate_tbilcat(
      tbil = TBIL, 
      tbiluln = TBILULN
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, TBIL, TBILULN, TBILCAT)
#> Formula to calculate TBILCAT: 
#>   if TBIL <= ULN then TBILCAT = 0
#>   if ULN < TBIL <= 1.5 × ULN then TBILCAT = 1
#>   if 1.5 × ULN < TBIL <= 3 × ULN then TBILCAT = 2
#>   if TBIL > 3 × ULN then TBILCAT = 3
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID      TBIL TBILULN TBILCAT
#>    <chr>       <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015   0.6     1.2       0
#>  2 01-701-1023   0.7     1.2       0
#>  3 01-701-1028   1.1     1.2       0
#>  4 01-701-1033   0.8     1.2       0
#>  5 01-701-1034   0.6     1.2       0
#>  6 01-701-1047   0.4     1.2       0
#>  7 01-701-1097   0.4     1.2       0
#>  8 01-701-1111   0.4     1.2       0
#>  9 01-701-1115   0.5     1.2       0
#> 10 01-701-1118   0.7     1.2       0
#> # ℹ 244 more rows
Example 2

All or some of expected variables are missing. In this case, the function will try to detect those missing variables from the parent environment:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    TBILCAT = calculate_tbilcat()
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, TBIL, TBILULN, TBILCAT)
#> TBIL variable found and used for the tbil argument.
#> TBILULN variable found and used for the tbiluln argument.
#> Formula to calculate TBILCAT: 
#>   if TBIL <= ULN then TBILCAT = 0
#>   if ULN < TBIL <= 1.5 × ULN then TBILCAT = 1
#>   if 1.5 × ULN < TBIL <= 3 × ULN then TBILCAT = 2
#>   if TBIL > 3 × ULN then TBILCAT = 3
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID      TBIL TBILULN TBILCAT
#>    <chr>       <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>

#>  2 01-701-1023   0.7     1.2       0
#>  3 01-701-1028   1.1     1.2       0
#>  4 01-701-1033   0.8     1.2       0
#>  5 01-701-1034   0.6     1.2       0
#>  6 01-701-1047   0.4     1.2       0
#>  7 01-701-1097   0.4     1.2       0
#>  8 01-701-1111   0.4     1.2       0
#>  9 01-701-1115   0.5     1.2       0
#> 10 01-701-1118   0.7     1.2       0

calculate_astcat

The calculate_astcat function is to Calculate AST Category. Following is the formula to calculate it: 
if AST 

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs.
Following are the inputs:
  • ast: Aspartate Aminotransferase (U/L). Numeric vector.
  • astuln: Reference Range Upper Limit (same units as observed values). Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    ASTCAT = calculate_astcat(
      ast = AST, 
      astuln = ASTULN
    )
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, AST, ASTULN, ASTCAT)
#> Formula to calculate ASTCAT: 
#>   if AST <= ULN then ASTCAT = 0
#>   if ULN < AST then ASTCAT = 1
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID       AST ASTULN ASTCAT
#>    <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>

calculate_nciliv

The calculate_nciliv function is to Calculate NCI Liver Fx Group (NCILIV). Following is the formula to calculate it: 
if TBILCAT = 0 and ASTCAT = 0 then NCILIV = 0
if TBILCAT = 0 and ASTCAT = 1 then NCILIV = 1
if TBILCAT = 1 then NCILIV = 2
if TBILCAT = 2 then NCILIV = 3
if TBILCAT = 3 then NCILIV = 4

This function returns a numeric vector the same length as its inputs. Following are the inputs:

  • tbilcat: Total Bilirubin Category. Numeric vector.
  • astcat: Aspartate Aminotransferase Category. Numeric vector.

Examples

Example 1

All expected variables are provided:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    NCILIV = calculate_nciliv(tbilcat = TBILCAT, astcat = ASTCAT)
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, TBILCAT, ASTCAT, NCILIV)
#> Formula to calculate NCILIV: 
#>   if TBILCAT = 0 and ASTCAT = 0 then NCILIV = 0
#>   if TBILCAT = 0 and ASTCAT = 1 then NCILIV = 1
#>   if TBILCAT = 1 then NCILIV = 2
#>   if TBILCAT = 2 then NCILIV = 3
#>   if TBILCAT = 3 then NCILIV = 4
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID     TBILCAT ASTCAT NCILIV
#>    <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015       0      1      1
#>  2 01-701-1023       0      0      0
#>  3 01-701-1028       0      0      0
#>  4 01-701-1033       0      0      0
#>  5 01-701-1034       0      0      0
#>  6 01-701-1047       0      0      0
#>  7 01-701-1097       0      0      0
#>  8 01-701-1111       0      0      0
#>  9 01-701-1115       0      0      0
#> 10 01-701-1118       0      0      0
#> # ℹ 244 more rows
Example 2

All or some of expected variables are missing. In this case, the function will try to detect those missing variables from the parent environment:

dmcognigen_cov %>% 
  mutate(
    NCILIV = calculate_nciliv()
  ) %>% 
  select(USUBJID, TBILCAT, ASTCAT, NCILIV)
#> TBILCAT variable found and used for the tbilcat argument.
#> ASTCAT variable found and used for the astcat argument.
#> Formula to calculate NCILIV: 
#>   if TBILCAT = 0 and ASTCAT = 0 then NCILIV = 0
#>   if TBILCAT = 0 and ASTCAT = 1 then NCILIV = 1
#>   if TBILCAT = 1 then NCILIV = 2
#>   if TBILCAT = 2 then NCILIV = 3
#>   if TBILCAT = 3 then NCILIV = 4
#> # A tibble: 254 × 4
#>    USUBJID     TBILCAT ASTCAT NCILIV
#>    <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1 01-701-1015       0      1      1
#>  2 01-701-1023       0      0      0
#>  3 01-701-1028       0      0      0
#>  4 01-701-1033       0      0      0
#>  5 01-701-1034       0      0      0
#>  6 01-701-1047       0      0      0
